head.title: On the Late Fire11 Published in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (May 18, 1796), p. 3. Turnbull’s poem was written in response to a widespread fire in Charleston on May 16, 1796, allegedly set by the black servant of a Santo Domingo refugee. Published a mere two days after the fire, the poem was possibly intended for declamation at the theatrical benefit staged for the disaster relief fund.

lg.l: You, who midst affluence and riches plac’d,
Whose halls with gorgeous furniture are grac'd;
Whose dainty viands load the groaning board,
And chests encumbered with the precious hoard,
Securely sit in luxury and ease—
Build not your happiness alone on these:
These earthly treasures in a single hour
The flood may sweep, or raging flames devour.
Let virtue be the treasure you adore,
And Fortune’s spite can never make you poor
‘Twas dead of night; free’d from the toils of day,
In slumber’s chains the peaceful city lay;
The Miser quite forgot his worldly cares,
The Politician all his state affairs;
The noisy Bacchanal22 Drunken revelry; derived from the Roman God of Wine, Bacchus. forgot to roar:
Riot and Dissipation rag’d no more—
When sudden from the silent dwellings broke
Devouring flames and suffocating smoke:
The dreadful bell the slumb’ring town alarms,
And drums, like rolling thunders, beat to arms;
The smoke, in blackening columns, rises high,
The curling flames gleam horrid in the sky;
From dours the windows bursts the dreadful blaze,
The wasteful ruin spread an hundred ways;
From place to place, accumulating force,
The conflagration spreads its rapid course:
Quick as the lightning from the clouds descends,
As quick the furious element extends;
Loud groans each bursting roof, and tumbling wall,
The enflaming brands, from high, destructive fall;
The devastation rages unconfined,
And wider spreads, borne by the rushing wind:
In vain the industrious citizens exert
The force of labour, and the power of art;
Pale fear and horror ev’ry heart confound
While universal ruin spreads around
How can the muse the dreadful tale relate?
How pain in colours true the dismal fate
Of each industrious citizen and friend,
Who must beneath this dire misfortune bend?
Those who their hardy yourths in toil have spent,
Now under age and locks all hoary bent,
Behold the fruits of many toilsome days
Torn from their children in one cruel blaze,
And now depriv’d of all their care could save,
To sink in want and sorrow to the grave.
Say who the ways of Providence can scan?
Where tell the destiny of wretched man?
He, who in regal purple, sits in state,
Can not award the ruthless hand of fate;
To day he rises mighty over all—
To-morrow’s sun shall see the mighty fall
Then man exist not in the hoards or wealth,
But bless thy God for competence and health!
If more the hand of Heav’n is pleas’d to give,
Be proud the wants of sorrow to relieve:
So may what thou in Charity hath given,
Be doubly paid thoe by indulgent heaven.
